item.title: Hugo vs. Jekyll: a showdown of static site generator
item.description: Last week, I mentioned that this site is built using Jekyll, a static site generator that, once you get used to it, is much faster to load and more convenient than dynamic content management system such as Wordpress. (Update: this site now runs on Hugo) Jekyll is way too slow Jekyll is a good alternative to things like Wordpress, but it isn’t without its own problem: the loading speed of the compiled static pages may be very fast because they are static, but those pages take a long time to build.

item.title: How to create a super-fast Jekyll site
item.description: (Update: this site now runs on Hugo) Earlier, I wrote a brief note explaining why I use Jekyll, which came down to two major factors: cost and performance. Hosting a Jekyll site on Github is free, eliminating all the costs (save the domain name) associated with running a self-hosted Wordpress site; and Github Pages is very fast. But there are still some room for improvments. The steps outlined below are what I’ve done to optimise my website, partly inspired by David Ensinger’s post on the same topic.

item.title: Jekyll: a static site generator
item.description: (Update: this site now runs on Hugo) For a long time, Wordpress was my go-to software to create website. It is free, has a huge community, massive collection of plugins, is not too difficult to set up for basic use, and is capable of running big and complex website.
